Fig. 3 Data for the monoligated set of candidates. The histogram shows the distribution of the three search criteria, while the scatter shows the poor correlation between them, with the NCMe binding energy shown by a colour scale. The energies are defined in Fig. 2. Fig. 4 Data for the biligated heteroleptic set of candidates. The histogram shows the distribution of the three search criteria. In comparison, the scatter shows a poor correlation between the two barrier criteria, with NCMe binding energy encoded by a colour scale. The energies are defined in Fig. 2. Fig. 5 Data for the biligated homoleptic set of candidates. The histogram shows the distribution of the three search criteria. The scatter shows the poor correlation between the two energy barrier criteria, with the NCMe binding energy encoded by a colour scale. The energies are defined in Fig. 2. Fig. 6 Averages of the three search criteria for each of the three data sets with error bars showing one standard deviation on either side of the mean. Fig. 7 Scatter plot of all data points from all three data sets. Numbered points are systems selected for further analysis. The “ideal region” containing complexes 3–12 is where a compromise of low barriers and NCMe binding is found between the two groups of points representing the biligated (right-hand side cluster) and monoligated (left-hand side cluster) systems. Complexes 1 and 2 represent candidates with low barriers. The energies are defined in Fig. 2. Fig. 8 Ligands that form complexes 1–12 selected for further analysis. The homoleptic systems are truncated showing only one of the two identical ligands bound to Pd(0). The heteroleptic systems have two distinct ligands labelled “A” and “B”. Fig. 9 Difference between the solvated ΔG OA barrier for the activation of PhCl and a phenyl carbonate, carbamate and sulfamate substrate using catalysts 1–12. Numbers above the bars are the PhCl OA barrier for each system. The bond shown in red is the one activated by the Pd centre. The carbamate OA TS for 5 could not be optimised. Graphical abstract We report a three-dimensional virtual screening method to search a chemical space formed of ligands from the tmQMg-L library for Pd Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling catalysts that has future potential to be applied to a broader range of catalytic reactions. It utilises three criteria related to important steps in the catalytic cycle of the reaction to distinguish between candidate Pd(0) species, namely the oxidative addition and reductive elimination barriers and the binding energy of acetonitrile. This method ultimately leads to identifying a region of chemical space that provides a good compromise between the three search criteria, highlighting a smaller set of ligands that merits further exploration. After the screening, several candidates are confirmed as catalysts based on literature searches. We also found Pd(0) complexes with high potential in catalytic cross-couplings involving less reactive substrates that require the oxidative addition of strong C–O bonds. Keywords Cross-coupling reactions Suzuki–Miyaura reaction Catalysis Inactive substrates Virtual screening Data-driven DFT Oxidative addition Reductive elimination Solvation Data availability The data is available in the supporting information 1 Introduction Cross-coupling reactions [1–3] have become a powerful tool in modern chemical synthesis with their importance highlighted when the work of Negishi [4], Heck [5] and Suzuki [6] was awarded the 2010 Nobel Prize in chemistry [7]. Of the many variants of cross-coupling reactions, the Suzuki–Miyaura [8–10], first published in 1979 [11], is the one most commonly used in part due to the stability, affordability, and versatility of organoboron reagents [8] used as one of the coupling partners. It is the second most commonly used reaction in drug synthesis [12] and the most common C–C bond formation reaction in the field. Other applications found throughout the literature are also in organic and polymer synthesis [13,14] as well as asymmetric synthesis [15] of complex targets. At the core of these reactions is a metal complex acting as a catalyst, often a Pd0 active species, the ligands of which can affect many factors, including the rate, substrate scope and stereoselectivity [15] of the reaction. The important role played by the ligands leads to the search for novel improved catalysts being an active area of research [16], as well as the creation of libraries of ligands for such studies [17–20]. Using a range of ligands, various different approaches to the design of a novel improved catalyst have been employed and documented in the literature [21–23] with different focuses. One focus has been to minimise the impact of off-cycle side reactions [24], such as the irreversible comproportionation between the PdII pre-catalyst and the Pd0 active species to form a PdI dimer. Other related approaches include the detailed study of the reaction mechanism, aiming at identifying ways to increase turnover frequency [25], and the use of machine learning and other data-driven methods to explore larger chemical spaces enclosing these catalytic reactions [26–28]. In this work, a data-driven, 3-dimensional virtual screening approach has been employed to sample a range of ligands to move closer to an ideal Pd0 catalyst for the Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction by incorporating different aspects of previous search methods. Using these ligands, a range of monoligated and biligated systems have been constructed with this type of unsaturated system previously being identified as the active species in a Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction [29]. In taking this approach, the complexity of finding a catalytic system that performs well for different steps of the catalytic cycle (Fig. 1 ) can be captured in one method that identifies candidates with the best all-round compromise. To do this, we used the large, diverse, and synthesizable tmQMg-L library [18–20] to sample a wide range of ligands known to be bound to Pd in the Cambridge Structural Database. The three selected criteria the search is based upon (Fig. 2 ) are 1) the oxidative addition (OA) barrier, the first step in the catalytic cycle, and often the rate limiting step of the reaction [30,31]; 2) the reductive elimination (RE) barrier, the final step in the catalytic cycle that releases the product and the Pd0 active species to begin a new cycle, and; 3) the binding energy of the solvent (acetonitrile, NCMe), a proxy for the availability of the Pd0 active species in solution. The choice of NCMe was based on its small size, making it computationally affordable, ability to stabilize Pd(0) species through π-backdonation, and, being also a σ-donor, ability to account for the coordination of other small molecules that can potentially disrupt catalysis. In addition to solvation, other factors can reduce the concentration of the active species, including the formation of PdI dimers by comproportionation of Pd0 and a PdII species [32]. These three criteria were evaluated by means of DFT calculations and the results show they discriminated satisfactorily between the systems. A region of chemical space between two clusters of points corresponding to monoligated and biligated systems yields a good compromise between all three criteria, enabling the selection of candidates for further analysis. 2 Method A set of 500 ligands was selected from the tmQMg-L library containing ligands extracted from structures in the Cambridge Structural Database. The selection was based on the following filters: bound to Pd, monodentate, neutral, dentic (non-haptic) and either P-, N-, C-, or O-bound to the metal centre. Only the largest 500 ligands, based on atom count, were selected for the study due to being better suited for unsaturated Pd0 centres. This selection approach did not include any specific rule relating to what could be expected to be an optimal ligand for cross-coupling catalysis. The process of building the required Pd complexes was automated using the molSimplify software package [33], with five systems generated for each candidate catalytic system to allow the calculation of the three criteria used in the screening (Fig. 2). As a model reaction, we used the coupling of PhCl to PhBX2 yielding biphenyl as a product. The BX2 fragment is not part of any of the five geometries required for the calculation of the criteria and, therefore, it does not need to be defined. These geometries are: the RE transition state (TS), the OA TS, the intermediate prior to RE (LnPdPh2), the solvated active species (LnPd(NCMe)), and the active Pd species (LnPd). If any geometry gave a “bad job” warning in molSimplify, usually due to atoms being too close together (i.e. steric clashes), the ligand combination was discarded. Therefore, with the aim of minimizing computational costs, the two TS systems were the first to be generated in the molSimplify workflow since they were the most likely to fail. The geometries passing these filters were optimised at a DFT level using the Gaussian16 program [34], yielding the three criteria. In order to approximate the TS structures, and avoid the expensive calculation of the Hessian matrices, constrained geometry optimisations were carried out, freezing only these internal coordinates: for the OA of PhCl, d(C–Cl) = 2.07 Å, α(C(para)–C(ipso)–Cl) = 152.02°, and for the RE of biphenyl, d(C(ipso)–C(ipso)) = 2.13 Å, α(C(para)–C(ipso)–C(ipso)) = 144.07° on both sides. These parameters were determined as an average over a smaller test set of systems where OA and RE TS geometries were fully optimised using 25 manually selected ligands. This approach was benchmarked for the OA step, where the cleaving C–Cl bond distances varied up to 0.25 Å, yielding a strong correlation (R2 = 0.934) between the barriers derived from constrained and fully relaxed TS geometries. In principle, this protocol can be generalized to other reactions, including alkyl and heteroaryl substrates. However, it should be noted that the constrained geometry approach may not account for changes in the nature of the mechanism and the associated TSs (for example, from a 3- to a 5-centered OA TS when varying the substrate), which can cause convergence problems. Further, considering both the PdL and PdL2 formulations can bias the ligand size towards small values due to the higher steric requirements of the latter formulation. For the NCMe calculations, the initial guess was based on the end-on coordination, allowing for isomerization to side-on through fully relaxed geometry optimizations. The molSimplify option of pre-optimising the structures using a force field was used for all three intermediates, LnPdPh2, LnPd and LnPd(NCMe), to give the best starting structure for the DFT optimisation. It was not used for the two constrained TS structures in order to maintain the geometry constraints. By using this protocol, three sets of 500 candidate catalysts, each with the five aforementioned systems required, were attempted to be generated; a monoligated set whereby only one ligand is bound to the Pd centre, a homoleptic set where two identical ligands are bound to the metal centre and a heteroleptic set where two different ligands are present. As there are more than 500 ligand combinations possible to make a heteroleptic complex, 500 ligand pairs were chosen at random to give a sample of the entire chemical space. Altogether, this makes a space of 1500 Pd complexes that were explored. The DFT optimisation of the molSimplify geometries was carried out using Gaussian 16 Rev C.01 [34] and the PBE [35] functional with the def2-TZVP basis set for Pd, including the corresponding effective core potential, and the def2-SVP [36] basis set for all other elements. All structures were fully optimised except for the geometric constraints of the TSs used to approximate the OA and RE energy barriers. If any of the five systems failed to optimise, the associated ligand combination was discarded since all five geometries are required to define the three criteria analysed in the screening. A subsequent single point of all candidates was then carried out using the PBE0 [37] functional to refine their energies, which were those used for the screening. For the harder to activate, C–O containing substrates, the OA ΔG barriers were calculated by using the single-point PBE0 energy with implicit PCM solvation [38] by acetonitrile (chosen as it is a commonly used solvent in Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reactions), including also the free energy corrections from the PBE optimisation and frequency calculations. All barriers and reaction energies are potential (ΔE) except for the activation of the inactive C–O substrates, for which free energy barriers are given (ΔG‡). 3 Monoligated systems Using the 500 ligands selected from the tmQMg-L library, the three TS and two intermediate structures (see the methods section) were built for the monoligated set. Fig. 3 shows data for the monoligated set of 276 successful candidates after structure generation, optimisation, and single point calculation. Of the 224 systems that did not make the final dataset, the vast majority failed for one of these two reasons: 1) optimising the RE TS, the most sterically crowded of the five structures, often caused failures mostly due to bad geometries from molSimplify, due to steric clashes; 2) optimising the acetonitrile-solvate due to the NCMe ligand dissociating from the Pd centre. Both of these issues caused one of the three criteria metrics to be missing and therefore, these candidates were removed from the study. Fig. 3 shows the distribution and correlation of the three energies defined in Fig. 2. The histogram shows the RE barriers of the systems narrowly and mostly normally distributed over a range of ca. 10 kcal mol−1 whereas, in contrast, the OA barriers span a wider range of ca. 20 kcal mol−1. This shows that ligand modifications have a greater impact on the OA step, which aligns with previous studies [39]. The OA barriers being negative are due to being based on the potential energy, where free energy would increase the barrier by approximately 12–15 kcal mol−1, and using separated PhCl and Pd0 species as the energy reference instead of a pre-bound Pd0(PhCl) intermediate. In general, the monoligated systems appear as favourable catalysts in terms of the reaction barriers, with both being easily assessable at room temperature. This matches previous studies in the literature showing how monoligated Pd0 species with bulky ligands facilitate OA [40] when the rates of mono and biligated systems are compared [25,41]. However, the OA and RE barriers are not the only criteria used in the screening. Regarding the NCMe binding energy to the Pd0 complex, most systems lie between −20 and −40 kcal mol−1, making binding of solvents (and likely the PdII pre-catalyst species) significantly favourable, which is not desirable for catalysis. The limited steric shielding introduced by a single ligand and the unsaturated nature of the Pd0 centre leads to the facile addition of another species to the metal centre, giving a favourable binding energy. This makes the active Pd0 species likely to engage in undesired off-cycle processes that reduce the efficiency of the catalyst. The scatter plot also presented in Fig. 3 shows the two barriers represented against each other with the NCMe binding energy encoded by a colour scale changing from dark red (exergonic) to dark green (endoergic), through orange and yellow (thermoneutral). The OA and RE barriers appear poorly correlated and clustered around mean values of −14.0 and +2.7 kcal mol−1 for OA and RE, respectively. All clustered points have a red colour indicating the favourable, unwanted binding of NCMe. In general, this data shows that the monoligated systems have low OA and RE barriers but a high affinity for NCMe coordination as an intrinsic property. In this first screening, the only data points that approached thermoneutrality in NCMe addition were those that deviated from the cluster showing also the higher barriers, suggesting the mutually exclusive relationship between these targets. 4 Heteroleptic biligated systems Fig. 4 shows the data obtained for 278 of the 500 heteroleptic biligated systems that were initially constructed. The loss of the NCMe ligand is also prevalent in this set, with the two ligands often forming a linear complex after eliminating NCMe. Both the OA and RE barriers for the heteroleptic set are higher than the monoligated systems but are still accessible, with most lying between 0 and 20 kcal mol−1. The largest change is in the OA barrier, in line with the unsaturated PdL species being replaced by PdL2. In contrast, the NCMe binding energy is more positive than the monoligated systems, with most lying between −10 and 10 kcal mol−1, as indicated by the yellow-to-green colour shades of the data points in the scatter plot (Fig. 4). This makes the binding of NCMe thermodynamically disfavoured in some cases, meaning the Pd0 species will likely be more available to undergo OA, increasing turnover frequency. Compared to the monoligated complexes, another significant difference is the larger data spread for all three criteria, which can be related to greater variance introduced by the presence of two different ligands. Further, the OA and RE barriers also appear largely uncorrelated in this set. 5 Homoleptic biligated systems The biligated homoleptic data set (Fig. 5 ) contains significantly fewer systems that were successful than the other two sets, with only 47 of 500 candidates having all five systems successfully optimised. The issues discussed for the heteroleptic complexes are prevalent in this set and, in particular, many more geometries failed to generate. Compared to the heteroleptic biligated set, since both ligands are the same, the geometries built with the larger ligands are the most sterically encumbered possible in the chemical space associated with the library of 500 ligands. This further increased the failure rate of the DFT calculations and, in particular, the molSimplify structure generation underlying the screening process. 6 Trends over the three sets Interestingly, the heteroleptic (Fig. 4) and homoleptic (Fig. 5) data collected for the biligated complexes are similar with the OA and RE barriers appearing largely uncorrelated over nearly the same ranges, which are wider than that observed for the monoligated complexes (Fig. 3). These similarities between the biligated sets are also reflected in the averages of the OA and RE barriers (Fig. 6 ), which are very close. Another common feature is the distribution of the NCMe binding data, which appears close to 0 kcal mol−1, with many complexes yielding a moderately endoergic reaction, though at the cost of involving higher barriers, when compared to the monoligated set. The monoligated set has lower average barriers and heavily exergonic NCMe binding. The smaller average values of the OA barriers relative to the RE can be ascribed to the Pd0 + PhCl origin of energies, which was used instead of Pd0(PhCl) for the sake of computational efficiency in the virtual screening. To best compare the data from the three sets of metal complexes, and look at individual systems, a scatter plot of the two barrier criteria is shown in Fig. 7 , using the same colour encoding of the NCMe binding energy used in Figs. 3–5. This scatter shows two distinct clusters of data points relating to 1) the monoligated systems on the left, with low barriers but favourable, yet detrimental NCMe binding (red/orange points), and 2) the biligated homoleptic and heteroleptic systems on the right, with higher barriers but unfavoured NCMe binding (yellow/green points). This data clearly shows that the two optimal properties for catalysis, that is, low OA and RE barriers, and endoergic NCMe binding, are mutually exclusive. However, between the two densely populated data clusters, the plot also shows a less densely populated region where the fringe points of the two groups meet. These systems points can be seen to represent a compromise between the three criteria screened, thus defining a region in property space labelled as “ideal” in the plot, which should comprise the most promising catalyst candidates. With the aim of exploring the ideal region of chemical space further, four candidates from each of the three data sets were selected, the structures of which are shown in Fig. 8 . The selection represents a wide range of sizes and types of ligands, some common and some more unusual in their nature, all originating from the CSD database and thus known to have been made in the lab. The ligand types include phosphines, imines, carbenes, phosphites, and amines. The monoligated, biligated homoleptic, and biligated heteroleptic candidates are 1–4, 5–8, and 9–12, respectively. Complexes 1 and 2, which have very low barriers with moderately endoergic NCMe binding, were also selected as references for further studies. All selected ligands (1–12) in Fig. 8 gave at least one hit when searched in the CSD database due to it being a prerequisite for being included in the tmQMg-L ligand library (Table 1 ). Some systems had multiple hits, with 7 having the highest number (20), followed by 2 (11) and 4, (7). A similar number of hits for each system is seen in the SciFinder database with notable exceptions being 4 (27) and 7 (200). These searches suggest that the twelve candidates contain both common and uncommon ligands. Some ligands also have hits for being bound to other metals, which were not counted. Exploring the CSD and SciFinder hits in greater detail, we found that some ligands have already been reported in catalytic systems promoting the Suzuki–Miyaura reaction (Table 1). For example, a close relationship to 6 was found for a biligated homoleptic catalyst [49], with the only difference being the Br atom of the Ph group being exchanged for F, which, being far from the metal centre, is unlikely to have much effect on catalytic activity. Ligands closely related to 9B have also been used for Suzuki–Miyaura reactions binding through C in the five membered heterocycle instead of through N. The ligand in candidate 7 was used as part of a catalyst with different ligands occupying other coordination sites of Pd [50]. The same is also true for ligand 11A [54]. This shows that the ideal region identified in the screening (Fig. 7) does provide systems with ligands that make suitable catalysts for the Suzuki–Miyaura reaction. Further, the ligand of 4 was used as part of a catalytic system for the Buchwald-Hartwig [47] and Heck [48] cross-coupling reactions, the ligand in 2 was used for hydroamination reactions [42–46], and the ligand in 7 was used for annulation reactions of alkynes and silirenes [51] and Heck reactions [52]. This shows the ability of the screening to find catalysts for similar reactions, including other cross-couplings. The search also identifies ten ligands without catalysis precedent in the literature which may also be active in the activation of PhCl and other, less active substrates. For the ligands for which there is no precedent (1, 3, 5, 8, 9A, 10A, 10B, 11B, 12A, 12B; Fig. 8 and Table 1), our screening may encourage the work of experimental groups aiming at finding novel catalysts for cross-coupling reactions. However, it should be noted that there are several factors not considered in the computational screening that may limit catalytic activity in experimental lab tests, including detrimental side reactions involving the ligands. 7 Inactive substrates Further analysis of the selected systems was also carried out by varying substrates undergoing OA. The initial catalyst search used PhCl as the model substrate since it is often used experimentally in Suzuki–Miyaura reactions. It is also convenient from a computational perspective due to its simplicity in a framework in which a large number of DFT calculations are required. Other, more difficult-to-activate substrates have been used in Suzuki–Miyaura reactions in which the OA breaks stronger bonds than the carbon-halide ones [55–58]. Alternative popular substrates include carbonates, carbamates and sulfamates [59], where a carbon–oxygen bond is activated. Compared to the halides, interest in these substrates originates from the more environment-friendly nature of the reaction by-products. However, these substrates are significantly more difficult to activate, requiring higher temperatures to extremes that can be incompatible with the stability of one or more components of the catalytic system. In this regard, the ability of a given catalyst to activate these substrates at a reasonable temperature (for example, at or below the boiling point of the solvent, which for NCMe is 82 °C) is a meaningful indicator of its scope. Fig. 9 shows the free energy difference between the fully optimised OA barriers for the test PhCl substrate and three substrates requiring C–O bond activation, a carbonate, a carbamate and a sulfamate (the full substrate structures are shown at the bottom of Fig. 9). The fully optimised PhCl barrier was obtained by re-computing the restricted TS geometry after removing all geometry constraints. To optimise the TS for the substrates containing C–O bonds, structures were built manually by modifying the fully optimised PhCl TS geometries. 3-center TS were optimised in all cases for the C–O containing substrates (analogous to those observed for the PhCl TS structures), except in five cases where they could not be located. In these instances, 5-centre TS geometries have been optimised whereby the O atom in the C–O being broken does not end bound to Pd, but a geminal O atom instead. The cases where these TS geometries are used are 5 with the sulfamate reagent, 10 with the carbamate reagent and 6 with all three C–O substrates. 3-centre TS structures for OA TS have previously been found to be more stable for bidentate ligands [60] which are similar in steric hindrance to the biligated systems. Both 1 and 3 have a large propensity to become bidentate and all ligands in the study were chosen as they were bulky, increasing steric hindrance and therefore making a 3-center TS lower in energy. The carbamate TS for candidate 5 could not be optimised for either geometry despite numerous attempts. Across all the selected candidates, an increase in the OA ΔG barrier of between 11.2 and 23.0 kcal mol−1 is seen for the three C–O containing substrates relative to the respective ΔG PhCl barrier for each system. The barrier calculated using the fully optimised PhCl OA TS geometries for systems in the ideal region (3–12) is between 8.8 and 33.0 kcal mol−1, and the low barrier systems, 1 and 2, have a barrier of −4.9 and 9.3 kcal mol−1 respectively (shown above the bars in Fig. 9). The barrier for the more difficult to activate substituents is thus accessible at reasonable temperatures for some of the systems with lower PhCl OA barriers. Other than systems 4 and 6, the increase in barrier associated with the sulfamate substrate is the lowest of the three which, therefore, is the easiest to activate as seen experimentally with higher yields obtained for the activation of sulfamates relative to carbonates and carbamates [59]. In all cases but 10 and 12, the carbamate barrier increase is the highest in line with the relative strengths of the C–O bonds in these substrates. The monoligated systems, 1–4, show some of the highest increases in barrier with the more difficult OA substrates of between 15.4 and 23.0 kcal mol−1. This may in part be due to these systems having the lower PhCl barriers meaning a large increase in barrier is not necessarily a disqualifying factor from them being suitable catalysts. All three substrates with 1 and 2, as well as some substrates with 3, have an overall C–O barrier below 30 kcal mol−1, which can be accessible at solvent boiling temperatures. The systems selected especially for their low OA and RE barriers, 1 and 2, gave the largest (23.0 kcal mol−1 for carbamate) and smallest (15.4 kcal mol−1 for sulfamate) increases in barriers, respectively, for the monoligated systems, yielding lower barriers than those of 3 and 4 when considering the PhCl OA reference. However, systems 3 and 4 do have the advantage of a less favoured binding of NCMe (Fig. 7), and from this perspective, 3 is predicted to perform better than 2. Interestingly all of the ligands in 1–4 are not known to be active catalysts for a Suzuki–Miyaura reaction. Biligated systems, 5–12, on average have a larger variance and a smaller increase in barrier (on average, 17.5 kcal mol−1 for monoligated systems, 14.4 kcal mol−1 for biligated systems) though they have higher PhCl OA barriers. Candidates 6 and 12 have some of the smallest increases of the twelve selected systems when moving to the C–O containing substituents. 6 has the smaller PhCl OA barrier of the two meaning the small increase in OA barrier with the C–O substrate still means the barrier is reasonably accessible. The origin of these two ligands differ with 6 sharing a very close similarity to a previously used ligand for the Suzuki–Miyaura reaction [49] (Table 1) whereas in contrast, neither of the ligands that comprises candidate 12 has been previously used for a cross-coupling reaction. Some other promising candidates are 5 and 11. 5 has an increase in sulfamate barrier that is comparable to that of the barrier increases seen for 6 and 12 but has a larger increase in barrier when it comes to the carbonate substrate. As 5 has a lower PhCl OA barrier of 17.1 kcal mol−1 the increase in barrier with the sulfamate substrate should be easily accessible. The literature search showed that the ligand in 5 has not been used before in cross-coupling reactions making it a potential novel catalyst for a Suzuki–Miyaura reaction. 11 has a lower increase in barrier for sulfamate that is comparable to 5 but a higher PhCl OA barrier making it less suitable. One of its ligands, 11A, has been used for Suzuki–Miyaura cross-couplings [54]. 8 Conclusion This paper has outlined a novel approach to searching for potential catalysts for a Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction by using a 3-dimensional screening process. A selection of monodentate ligands from the tmQMg-L dataset that are known to have been bound to Pd before has given a large series of potential candidates that have been screened. The results show that the criteria selected satisfactorily discriminate between the different candidates in order to determine potential leads to select for further analysis. The biligated (both hetero- and homoleptic) and monoligated systems form two groupings in a plot of OA barrier against RE barrier (Fig. 7), with the region between them giving a good compromise between the three criteria. This highlighted a region that would benefit from further investigation. Selected systems in this region of the plot show that some of them contain ligands, or close analogues of ligands, previously reported for use in Suzuki–Miyaura and other related cross-coupling reactions, as well as novel ligands for this application, indicating that this is a promising region to search in. Testing the versatility of some of these systems by using some non-traditional coupling partners for the OA step where the activation of C–O bonds in carbonates, carbamates and sulfamates is required, shows that some of the candidates from the ideal region still have accessible barriers. From this, candidates 5, 6, 11 and 12 have a lower increased barrier when moving to the more difficult to activate substrates. In particular, 5 and 6 stand out by having also a low PhCl OA barrier. With 6 being a close analogue to an existing catalyst and 5 being a novel complex for use as a ligand in a Pd mediated Suzuki–Miyaura reaction, this shows the region of chemical space identified is a good place to search. All the monoligated systems, 1–4, have accessible barriers for the more difficult substrates, with two having some related use before. It should be noted that the present study was designed after assuming that transmetalation is not the rate determining step, when there are examples suggesting the opposite for some concrete systems; for example, with aryl-nickel(II) species [61]. Further, more focused searches within the high activity area identified would be required to find additional versatile candidates that have the correct compromise between the investigated criteria, though these results already demonstrated that the search method used here has potential to identify novel improved catalysts. It could also be applied to not only more ligand combinations or even metals for use in the Suzuki–Miyaura reaction, but also to other transition metal complex mediated processes where three criteria biased upon key steps in the catalytic cycle can be identified and screened against. This approach can also be augmented and become particularly useful in novel automation frameworks like DART [62]. coredata.dc:description: We report a three-dimensional virtual screening method to search a chemical space formed of ligands from the tmQMg-L library for Pd Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling catalysts that has future potential to be applied to a broader range of catalytic reactions. It utilises three criteria related to important steps in the catalytic cycle of the reaction to distinguish between candidate Pd(0) species, namely the oxidative addition and reductive elimination barriers and the binding energy of acetonitrile. This method ultimately leads to identifying a region of chemical space that provides a good compromise between the three search criteria, highlighting a smaller set of ligands that merits further exploration. After the screening, several candidates are confirmed as catalysts based on literature searches. We also found Pd(0) complexes with high potential in catalytic cross-couplings involving less reactive substrates that require the oxidative addition of strong C–O bonds.
